title: Valley Of Torment
opening: Your party travels to Ailell, the Valley of Torment, to meet up with allied troops and secure reinforcements. It should have been a safe march...

dialogue.speaker: Felix
dialogue.line: We received a reply from my father. You should read it too.

dialogue.speaker: Rodrigue
dialogue.line: Gilbert has filled me in on the details. He tells me you are in immediate need to additional troops. I would like to say that I will gather reinforcements and send them to the monastery at once... However, I cannot afford to leave the front lines for that long. Would you be willing to meet us south of Fraldarius territory in Ailell, the Valley of Torment? Ailell is halfway between the monastery and our territory. There, I will deliver the soldiers you require.

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: Ailell lies on the border between Kingdom territory and Alliance territory. Humans dare not approach that place.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: He's right. In Ailell, we can meet up with them without our enemy ever finding out.

dialogue.speaker: Felix
dialogue.line: Once my old man delivers his soldiers to us, then our war against the Empire can finally begin.

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: The path ahead will be a difficult one, Your Highness. Deadly, in all likelihood...

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: True. But what's the point in wavering now? Father, Stepmother, Glenn, and even Dedue... I am certain this will bring them great joy. I know if I can just offer them Edelgard's head... I just know it...

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: Go away.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Hmph. I am steeling myself to see my father again. I can't stand that old man.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: But he's your father.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: That's just biological circumstance. We may have the same blood, but we've nothing else in common.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You really hate him.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Yes, I do. Above all, I hate the crazed nonsense that comes out of his mouth.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: The Kingdom capital or the Imperial capital? I don't know which is the right way. If we tried to take on the Empire like this, would we really stand a chance? With House Fraldarius under attack, they probably can't spare many soldiers. On the other hand, if we did manage to take the Imperial capital, the war would be over. Hmm... I'm no good at thinking through this kind of complicated stuff.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Ailell, the Valley of Torment. Aw, man... I really do not want to go there.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Pull yourself together.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Professor, have you ever been to Ailell? If you had, you'd know.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Why not?

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: That place is crazy hot! For guys like me who grew up somewhere cold? Man... It's gonna be rough. Though, I guess that climate will keep our enemies at bay.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: I don't know about everyone else, but heading to the Empire seems like a good idea to me. The search for Lady Rhea will be so much easier if we can just get the Empire out of the way. I suppose Dimitri might still pose a problem though. He seems so fixated on the Imperial capital, but... I get the feeling he's not even sure what he wants anymore.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: If we can take back the Kingdom, we'll recover our soldiers. And some food and supplies too, I bet. Most importantly of all, there are people in the Kingdom waiting for our help. Even His Highness understands that. I'm sure of it. Yet he wants to take on the Empire despite all that... Do you think...he just doesn't care about anything other than fighting Edelgard anymore?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's not true.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: But if not, then why...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You may be right.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: He wasn't always like this. What happened...

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: It is imperative that we regroup with those who continue to resist. Most importantly, we must join up with the Fraldarius family. If we do, our ability to reclaim the Kingdom capital is ensured. We should aim for this outcome rather than focusing our efforts on the Imperial capital. This seems to me the best strategy at present. But I feel what His Highness feels--his hatred, his anger--so keenly, as if it were my own. So I find it difficult to oppose his wishes.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Some day we will take the Imperial capital. It is odd to think that I will be invading the very city that I once called home. Ah, that is still a ways off. I will prepare for our journey to Ailell.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: I never do get used to the sight of blood. It always makes me feel as if I might faint. I suppose I've told you that though, yes? I've no idea how you cope with it. I hope this war ends soon. I dislike being lightheaded because other people are bleeding everywhere. Though the thought of working hard for it does sound like quite a pain...

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: We weren't related by blood, but Randolph was still my uncle... Seeing him end up that way was... Never mind. It's nothing.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's how it goes with war.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: This wasn't just about war. It was a grudge. Or are you gonna tell me you're on Dimitri's side?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm so sorry.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: It's fine. I don't need your sympathy. It's not like I had any real connection with him anyway. But Dimitri's methods... I don't know...

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: I'm sure he never trusted me, being born in the Empire and all.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Ailell, the Valley of Torment? What kind of a name for a place is that? It sounds scary. Do I really have to go with you? Hey, um, here's an idea... Maybe let the recluse stay home and hold the fort!

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: This is all a bit troubling, isn't it? The people from the Kingdom seem to be of two minds, as well. Can we really plan to fight when we're this unsure of ourselves?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Maybe fighting will actually help...

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: You think once we're face to face with the enemy, it might help us band together? I hope so.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's hard to say.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Well, Professor, I hope you can bring everyone together. You might be the only person who can.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Since the past, I have learned much of the language of Fódlan. But speaking the Fódlan language still gives me difficulty. I can understand, read, and write with nearly perfection now. But understanding and speaking are...fruits of a different color.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's part of your charm.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: I have gratitude for you, Professor. I hope that I will have fluency one day.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Everyone has a weak spot.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Yes. I will keep practicing more.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Ugh...so...hungry... I won't be able to train if I don't get some food in me! I used to eat until I was full, but nowadays I can't even get seconds! Aren't reinforcements supposed to be joining us soon? I hope they bring food along with them... I still want my little sis to live in the town here, but there's no point if we can't even feed her!

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: The Valley of Torment... I'd heard of it, but I never expected to go there. It's exciting! I wonder what the landscape is like.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It sounds dangerous.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: It probably is dangerous, but I still want to get there and see it as soon as I can.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It sounds painful.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Hm, that is an interesting point... The name does seem to suggest that.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Ailell, the Valley of Torment, lies on the border of three noble territories. The Kingdom's Fraldarius and Galatea families, and the Alliance's Daphnel family. Incidentally, the Galatea family was originally an offshoot from the Daphnel family.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Valley of Torment... Valley of Torment...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Something wrong?

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I once read a book full of legends surrounding Ailell, but I can't seem to remember...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Are you chanting some sort of curse?

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: N-no... I'm trying to remember the legends surrounding Ailell...

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I feel there is something dreadful I'm forgetting.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: I heard we're headed to the Valley of Torment. I'm not exactly thrilled. That place is supposed to be really, really hot. Just the thought of it makes me uncomfortable.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You don't like hot climates?

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: I hate them! You get all sweaty and sticky and eugh!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You want to stay here?

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Ooh, that's not a bad idea! Though if our enemies attacked while I was here, that would be a pain too...

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Ugh! Who names a place Valley of Torment? A more inviting name would have been nice. Valley of Endless Summer, something like that!

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: You're not a teacher anymore, and we're not your students, but everyone still calls you Professor. Is there something you'd rather be called?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Professor is fine.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Guess that's what we're used to, huh? All right.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Call me by my name.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Oh? All right, then. I'll call you--ugh. Nope! Sorry, can't do it. Too weird.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: Meeting reinforcements in the Valley of Torment seems an astute decision to me. In that land of oppressive heat, it is unlikely that we will be disturbed. It also means we will need to contend with those harsh conditions ourselves, however. Best ensure we are well prepared.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: It has been only five years, yet so much has changed. Half of the Kingdom has fallen to the Empire. Skirmishes are rife throughout the Alliance. Despite such tumult, we look upon the same sky, unchanged by the storm happening beneath it.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Do you wish you could return to those days?

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Yes, it would be nice, I suppose. Things were...simpler then. Or so they seemed to be, at the time.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's true--it's just like it was all those years ago.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Indeed. I gazed up at this same sky with Mother and Father. It does not feel so long ago at all. Wait, but how would you know, Professor?

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: The monastery repairs have made solid progress. Most excellent news. When we first returned here, I was unsure what we were going to do with the ruins of this place... But if we can get the cathedral rebuilt, we'll have it looking just like old times soon enough.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Gilbert was a knight to the royal family of Faergus? What was a man like that doing in Garreg Mach, I wonder? Who knows. Whenever I try to ask about it, he'd change the subject and avoid giving a proper answer.

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: These past five years, Lord Rodrigue worried for His Highness more than any other. But I wonder what he would say if he saw what has become of Dimitri...

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: The Kingdom doesn't seem to have clear goals holding them together. Different people have different priorities. The situation right now is difficult. But at times like this, you have the opportunity to really shine, eh Professor? You're in charge. Show them what you're made of! I'll do what I can to help.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Strategically speaking, our best move is probably to head for the Kingdom capital. Though, I think it's more likely that Lady Rhea is in the Empire, so I would not object to taking the fight directly to Edelgard. Hm. There are no right or wrong answers in war. What do you think we should do? I hope, with the goddess's guidance, we can make the right choice.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: There are enemy spies around. Remain vigilant. Capture anyone who seems suspicious.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: To kill them?

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: What else would we do with them?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: All right, I will.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: I'm glad you understand. I'm counting on you.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Gotta clean out the storerooms, tend the flowers, do the washing, dust the library...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That sounds like a lot of work.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Well, it's my job, ya know? Gotta do your job.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Do you need any help?

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Nah, this is my job. Lady Rhea herself gave it to me. Even if Lady Rhea's not here right now, I still gotta do my duty.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Like you. You gotta have other stuff you oughta be doing, yeah?

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Is everyone setting out on a big campaign? Not exactly? Ah, so you're meeting up with the reinforcements. Well, you can leave guarding this place to me! I'll keep an eye out for anything suspicious!

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: This valley isn't a place I'd care to return to . . .

intro.speaker: Ingrid
intro.line: After the chilliness of Faerghus, I can't seem to adjust to this extreme heat.

intro.speaker: Sylvain
intro.line: Historically, there have been battles whose outcomes were determined in part by the climate. You can't argue that this heat isn't a factor.

intro.speaker: Ingrid
intro.line: In conditions like these, who knows what will become of our morale . . .

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Professor, be honest. How are you holding up?

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I'm at my limit.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Don't overexert yourself. Perhaps it would be best to take breaks as we proceed.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I never imagined it would be like this...

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Monks once used this area as an ascetic training ground because of the intense environment.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: They say Ailell was born of the goddess's rage...

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Her rage?

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I hadn't heard that before.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: If you believe the legends, this valley is evidence of the goddess's judgement...passed on humanity for its corruption. The forest that once covered the surrounding area was burnt to ash by a pillar of light that descended from the heavens. That legend fueled belief in a place of torment between our world and the next...where one's sins are purified in the cleansing flames.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: Nonsense. Sins are not so easily washed away.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Indeed ... And there are no accounts of such a place in scripture. Yet those who cannot face their own sins have no choice but to cling to the idea.

intro.speaker: Mercedes
intro.line: Ugh, I just don't think I can take this heat anymore. I think I'm starting to see things... Near those mountains over there.... Is it just me, or is there a group of people gathered there?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: No... It would seem you are not hallucinating after all.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: That is House Rowe's banner. They curried favor with that witch and sold out Faerghus.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: We messed up. There must have been a spy among us... Will you have us meet them in battle or wait for Rodrigue to arrive?

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: There is only one option. How kind of them to save us the trouble of killing them later.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Aren't they your former allies?

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: Never call those traitors our allies again.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: They sold out the Kingdom, right?

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: I will not repeat myself.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: That banner belongs to the Gray Lion. It's a waste of breath to exchange words with one such as him.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: His Highness is correct. He is not an opponent whom we can expect to negotiate with. Everyone! Prepare for the attack!

battle.speaker: Gwendal
battle.line: The Valley of Torment . . . Perhaps a good place to finish off my life as a knight. Only if that puny force of children is able to kill me, of course . . .

battle.speaker: Gilbert
battle.line: That man, who raises the Lion's flag? Lord Gwendal. He is an elder knight who serves House Rowe. Gwendal would, without thought, fight any battle if ordered. There is no chance of negotiating with him.

battle.speaker: Gilbert
battle.line: Ailell is a deadly place. Flames burst from the ground with no warning. Sane people usually avoid it.

battle.speaker: Dimitri
battle.line: So, the flames of torment burn your sins, your life, your everything. If you wish to spare yourself the goddess's wrath, tread lightly.

battle.speaker: Kingdom Soldier
battle.line: Here we go! Attack them from both sides!

battle.speaker: Rodrigue
battle.line: So Cornelia has planted spies even inside Garreg Mach.

battle.speaker: Gwendal
battle.line: The Shield of Faerghus has appeared! We can expect more out of him than the young ones.

battle-talk.speaker: Rodrigue
battle-talk.line: To meet you in a place like this... No, that won't do. I'll leave the talking until after the battle. Here's a small souvenir for you. Put it to good use.

boss.speaker: Gwendal
boss.line: Does a whelp like you really expect to kill me? I am Gwendal, the Gray Lion, a knight by the hand of Count Rowe! Do your worst!

boss.speaker: Gwendal
boss.line: Ah, so I have found a place to die . . . Young ones . . . I thank you . . .

boss.speaker: Dimitri
boss.line: The man praised as a lion is degraded to a mere traitor's underling.

boss.speaker: Gwendal
boss.line: A traitor's underling? That's upsetting, Your Highness. I am and always have been a knight of House Rowe.

boss.speaker: Dimitri
boss.line: How dare you? You are nothing but a lowly beast scavenging for scraps. You have forgotten the dignity of knighthood.

boss.speaker: Gwendal
boss.line: I may be lowly, but this beast is loyal to his master.

boss.speaker: Dimitri
boss.line: Ha! Then I had better kill a pet and deliver its head to that master . . .

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: It's been too long, Your Highness. But try to temper your joy, will you? This is a war, after all.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: To say such a thing at a time like this. You have not changed one bit.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Don't let looks deceive you. I've had a rough go of it ever since I crossed blades with those traitors in Fhirdiad. When I heard you'd been executed, I rushed there as fast as I could, blind with fury. When I got there, I was fed some garbage about not being able to see your body. The next thing I knew, I was gripping my blade and... Gilbert, you have done well to locate His Highness. I am truly grateful.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: And you... I have you to thank, as well.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: As his professor, it was my duty.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: We were all fortunate.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Well, we are in your debt. I will repay you for this someday, I swear it. And you, Felix... You have also done well to bring His Highness here.

end.speaker: Felix
end.line: Hmph.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Tell us all you know, Rodrigue.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: I'm afraid there's not much to tell. You are aware that the western region of the Kingdom was taken by the Empire, correct?

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Yes, so I have heard. They are now calling it the Faerghus Dukedom or some nonsense.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: If you know that much, then the rest won't take long. Enemy or not, it's undeniable that Cornelia's plan was nothing short of genius. After seizing power, she invited the Imperial army to Fhirdiad. There, she reorganized her troops and then sent soldiers to hunt me down. Because of that, we were forced to act defensively. And now we're being forced into a difficult battle. She's been controlling the situation all along.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: So that's been the witch's plan from the start. I should have killed her ages ago.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Your Highness... Fhirdiad is in a terrible state right now. The tyranny is unbearable, and so the rebellions are endless. Refugees starve to death in the streets. If I may speak freely, Your Highness... We should change course for Fhirdiad and take down those traitors before we embark to Enbarr.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: There's no time for that. We must annihilate Enbarr before all else.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Think this through. I understand wanting to destroy the Empire and the emperor. I want that so much it hurts. But which is more important, the dead or the living?

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: SILENCE.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: No, Dimitri, you will hear me out.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Are you asking me...asking the dead...to forgive that woman?

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: No, I would not ask that of you. What I am asking is that you allow us to prioritize the Kingdom capital over the Imperial capital for now. As Lambert's close and trusted friend, I am confident that he would have advised the same.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Do not dare to put words in the mouth of the dead. They are your words alone, even if you borrowed their lips. Until I offer up that woman's head, Father will remain a slave to his lingering regret and hatred... Even now, he suffers. It is ceaseless. As we waste time with idle chatter, his suffering continues!

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: You are my king. Our king. Wherever you lead, we will follow. But Your Highness... There are those who take up their sword in the name of revenge, and yet along the way, lose the strength and composure to follow through... You would do well to bear that in mind.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Ah, I nearly forgot. Take this, Your Highness. The time has come for it to be wielded by its true master.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Areadbhar... The Hero's Relic once wielded by my father.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: The very same. I managed to steal it back from one of Cornelia's underlings in Fhirdiad.

end.speaker: Felix
end.line: Understated as ever, Father. It must have been a true struggle to get it back.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: I... I am grateful, my friend.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Gilbert, Professor. May I request something of you? I wish to fight at your side.

end.speaker: Felix
end.line: Senile already, old man? Who will protect our territory?

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: I expected it would come to this, so I left those matters to my younger brother. He has my complete faith. I must keep my promise to our fallen king...to my dear friend.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: What promise?

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: A very old one. I swore it nearly 10 years ago. Now then, Your Highness. Let's destroy the Empire together. My men and I will spare no effort. I pray that you are right...and that this will save the Kingdom.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Our orders are to capture Enbarr by striking the enemy stronghold directly... How familiar are you with the geography of Fódlan?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Very familiar.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Then you must be aware that the Kingdom and the Empire are separated by the impassable Oghma Mountains, right?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Not very familiar.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: The Kingdom and the Empire are separated by the impassable Oghma Mountains.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Legend has it that Saint Seiros once crossed over those mountains to fight against the Fell King Nemesis... But don't fool yourself. Leading an army over such steep mountains would be near impossible.

end.speaker: Gilbert
end.line: In order to infiltrate the Empire, we have no choice but to go around the mountains, either to the east or to the west.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Let's go east.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Yes, I agree.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Let's go west.

end.speaker: Gilbert
end.line: Hmm. I believe that may be difficult. After all, the western region of the Kingdom is already loyal to the Empire. Perhaps we should consider going east...using the route that passes through Alliance territory.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: The Alliance is currently split in two. Those who stand with the Empire and those who are against it. Leading the Imperial faction is House Gloucester, while House Riegan leads those who oppose. We should take advantage of their internal conflict and proceed east along the mountains until we reach the Great Bridge of Myrddin in Alliance territory.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Why there?

end.speaker: Gilbert
end.line: The Airmid River divides Alliance and Empire territory. There are many large bridges that cross it. However, the Great Bridge of Myrddin is by far the largest, and it is also the closest to the monastery. I believe you crossed that bridge five years ago on your journey to the Battle of the Eagle and Lion.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: It's risky...

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: I'm afraid we have no other option. This is our only hope.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: What if the Empire and the Alliance both attack?

end.speaker: Gilbert
end.line: I'm afraid it's a possibility. But it's still more practical than passing through the west.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Perhaps our next move should be to contact House Riegan and request their cooperation...

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Do you think they'll help us?

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Claude of House Riegan is the leader of the Alliance and is firmly against the Empire. They are the enemy of our enemy... In other words, hopefully a friend.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Are you suggesting that we ask House Riegan to engage the Gloucester soldiers?

end.speaker: Gilbert
end.line: I am. If we take the bridge, then House Gloucester will no longer be able to receive help from the Empire. There's no way a man as wise as Claude would refuse our request.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: And once we manage to capture the Great Bridge and gain a foothold into the Empire...

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Then we cross Gronder Field and head south toward Enbarr.

end.speaker: Ashe
end.line: But if we get attacked from both sides, we'll have to fight people from the Alliance, won't we?

end.speaker: Mercedes
end.line: Speaking of House Gloucester, I wonder how Lorenz is holding up...

end.speaker: Annette
end.line: If we meet him again, it will probably be as enemies. To be honest, I'd rather avoid seeing him altogether.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: If you do not wish to kill familiar faces, do not tarry over the corpses of the dead.

end.speaker: Felix
end.line: Hmph. Good advice.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Prepare yourselves. It is time to steel your souls for the task at hand.
